posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: My team’s Reefscape robot used MAXSwerve with Vortexes and NEO 550s this season. I’m curious if there’s a quantifiable limitation of MAXSwerve only allowing 550s as turning motors or if there’s a noticeable point where the performance diminishes. Additionally, has anyone modified their modules to use a different type of turning motor besides the 550? We encountered so many issues with these components this season that removing them from future robots might be a viable option. Thanks!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: A larger motor tends to fail less frequently. However, there may also be some performance-related costs, but I don't believe they're massive.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: We just finished our third season with MAX swerve. Yeah, NEO 550s are tiny and awful, especially when it comes to those fragile encoder cables. We’re currently looking into either switching to CTRE Minions for turning, which would require a custom adapter, or jumping ship and moving away from Mark 4i. I’ll be sure to update this thread if we end up developing a Minion adapter.

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked: I want to completely switch to a different swerve system, but the cost is not cheap, especially after already spending so much on MAXSwerve. I'm thinking of making an adapter to use a regular NEO since we have a bunch of those lying around.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
What issues in particular are you having?

I’ve found 550s to be pretty reliable. Just be careful with the encoder cable and apply a little hot glue on the CAN bus connectors of the Spark Max.

To unplug the encoder cable, I usually use a small flathead screwdriver to gently pry out each side of the connector a bit at a time until it comes free.

Overall, though, once the 550 is properly installed, it performs like any other motor.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: I have found 550-series motors to be quite reliable. However, with anything above a 15A current limit, they are likely to fail before a full season of use. These motors are also highly sensitive to impacts and vibrations. Bigger motors may be stronger, but scaling laws play a significant role in performance.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: In my experience with the application, where I’ve set a 20A limit (which I believe aligns with the current recommendation in the MAXSwerve template), I haven’t encountered any issues. In fact, several neighboring teams have adopted MAXSwerve as well. However, one notable drawback is that the motors are exposed on top of the module, making them susceptible to damage from intakes or other components from other robots.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We’ve never had one burn out, but we’ve removed the encoder wiring. Ideally, you’d want to replace the 550 with something such as a Kraken X44, but integrating that would be quite complex in terms of packaging.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: Replacing the motor on a MAX swerve would be quite challenging. Everything below the Ultraplanetary system is custom hardware, and you may need to build your own components. I’m not sure if the Ultraplanetary system can accommodate a larger motor.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
Two possibilities exist for modifying a vehicle's steering system, both involving adaptation:

1. **Adapting NEO or SplineXS Motors**: One approach is to modify either a NEO or SplineXS motor to accept an UltraPlanetary input pinion. In theory, this involves truncating the motor's shaft and precision machining it to fit a press-on pinion. However, 3D-printed adapters may lack sufficient strength, so a custom adapter would likely be needed to connect the motor's bolt circle to the UltraPlanetary. This method could work, though it seems unconventional.

2. **Building a Custom Gearbox**: Another option is to fabricate a custom gearbox that accommodates a NEO or SplineXS motor while integrating with the steering gear. This would effectively replace the UltraPlanetary system entirely.

The user also advised: "If you prioritize a compact setup with high steering motor power, consider purchasing a SwerveX2S. While attempting to adapt the Maxswerve to a non-550 steering motor is challenging, it’s only advisable if you have a specific reason to do so."

posts.name: Emmett Sisson
posts.cooked:
The pinions on a group of them kept slipping, even after applying a significant amount of Loctite, which meant they would free-spin frequently, requiring us to take the entire mechanism apart. Additionally, the UltraPlanetary mounting on the module loosened quickly, though this may have been an error on our part.

Based on what people have said, converting the turning motor into a non-550 might be beyond my current skill level. I appreciate all the helpful advice everyone has provided!

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: The friction-fit pinion shouldn’t require an arbor press to attach; it should stay on securely without additional tools like threadlocker.

We’ve been running the same 550s at a 20-amp limit for three or more seasons, including those in our swerve modules, with absolutely no issues. As the turning motor is concerned, there’s very little worry about burnout since there’s no scenario where the motors stall, and even at 20 amps, you’d still have plenty of time before smoking a 550 if the wheel were to stall.

It’s also fairly easy to replace the encoder wires if you break them off—you’ll just need a JST connector set, crimper, and soldering iron (though technically not necessary, but it makes the process significantly easier). We even had to swap one out mid-competition after a falling coral landed on one of our encoder wires.

posts.name: Xavier E.
posts.cooked:
We’ve been using the MAXSwerve for three seasons now, and our only issues have been related to the sensor wires from the motors and the encoder wire. This year, we switched to NEO Vortexes and SparkFlexes, which we really enjoyed. I had hoped REV might upgrade the 550s to no longer require SparkMaxes, but perhaps that’s something to consider for the future.

Additionally, while the 550s don’t seem to limit anything with the MAXSwerve, I’d like the option to replace one with another motor if needed.

Retaining compound may work better than a regular thread locker for addressing a shaft slippage issue. However, slipping shafts on a 550-pinion definitely indicates a quality assurance (QA) issue and something you should contact REV about if you encounter it more frequently in the future.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We pulled one set of motor sense wires completely out of the motor—nothing left to solder or crimp to. We had to toss that one. Other sets of sense wires have broken and been repaired, mostly due to other robots getting into places we didn’t think possible.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: For what it's worth, I've encountered issues with press-fit pulleys on Neo550s before. Retaining compounds can help, though the shaft is quite small. This relates to the principle that larger motors tend to be more robust.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked: If I recall correctly, early NEO 550s models had quality issues related to the shaft diameter or finish. The recommended fix was to use locktite or retaining compound.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Since it’s a quality issue, the Original Poster should contact REV to request replacement motors. They are known for providing replacements for defects quickly.
